Award.AwardTitle: Social distress in midlife in Arizona: a mixed methods ethnographic case study

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Recently, epidemiologists have uncovered an unwelcome and unusual health trend in the United States: increasing death rates among non-Hispanic whites since 1999. This is a significant and sustained reversal of previous trends. Historically, increases in mortality have rarely occurred outside of war or epidemics. The rise was not seen for any other American ethnic group or in any other high income country. It is most severe among men and women who are 45 to 54 years of age, have a high school education or less, and are living in smaller metro and rural areas in the South and West census regions. It appears to be the result of increases in suicides and drug and alcohol abuse. However, the statistics can only reveal patterns. To get at underlying causes, it is necessary to also have smaller studies of social context and the distress driving the crisis. The research funded by this award addresses this need. Medical anthropologist Dr. Michelle A. Parsons, of Northern Arizona University, will undertake an ethnographic case study of life threatening social distress among middle-aged non-Hispanic whites in Arizona.

Dr. Parsons' preliminary hypothesis is that distress is associated with social integration, in particular a feeling of not being needed or not being useful, which is produced through specific political, economic, cultural, and institutional structures. She will explore this hypothesis with a mixed methods ethnographic case study. The research will be carried out among a midlife generation with lower levels of education in Yavapai County, which has one of the highest age-standardized midlife suicide rates in Arizona and is among the top ten highest rates among all U.S. counties. She will draw her sample from employees of the social institutions that are the largest employers in the county: healthcare institutions, government institutions, and social service providers. Methods include secondary analysis of publicly available datasets, participant observation, archival research, key informant interviews (n=40), structured interviews (n=200), and semi-structured in-depth interviews (n=80). A community advisory board will work with the research team and help with dissemination of research results and recommendations to county and state health and government organizations. The broader impacts of the research are threefold. First, findings from the study will improve understanding of midlife distress in an area of the U.S. with a very high rate of midlife suicide. This will enable recommendations for multilevel interventions to reduce distress and mortality. The research also will elucidate the social context of rising mortality, identifying factors potentially related to mortality increases in other areas of the United States. Finally, the project will advance knowledge in medical anthropology, sociology, and other disciplines, including public health, epidemiology, and clinical psychology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project used ethnographic, qualitative, and quantitative methods to investigate midlife mortality and community responses to distress in Yavapai County, as a case study of rising US midlife mortality. Ethnographic methods included participant observation at an emergency homeless shelter; qualitative methods included semi-structured interviews with key service providers (40) and service recipients, including guests of the shelter (14), participants in a reentry program for the formerly incarcerated (5), and individuals in a drug and alcohol rehabilitation program (16). Quantitative methods were used to analyze publicly available datasets and conduct a survey.

The research has thus far resulted in one co-authored article in Journal of Community Health (Parsons and Barger 2019), the submission of three other single-authored manuscripts to medical anthropology journals, one additional article in progress, and six presentations at anthropology conferences. Mortality in Yavapai County has risen since 1999, but this increase is not restricted to non-Hispanic whites, to midlife, or to drug-related deaths. The mortality crisis in Yavapai County affects non-Hispanic white and Hispanic adults aged 25–64, driven by suicides and alcohol and drug related deaths. The unemployed and those with low levels of education are particularly at risk. Data from the Yavapai County Overdose Fatality Review Board, on which I am a member, point to the importance of homelessness, mental health, and incarceration.

Additional analyses examine the relationship between work and substance use and the possibilities of institutional care. In one manuscript, “Care multiple and the problem of purification: Thoughts from an emergency homeless shelter” I build on work on care and ethics to show how the co-existence of seemingly incommensurate modes of care enable institutions to intentionally think about and experiment with care (submitted September 2020). In another manuscript, “The relationality of work and substance use in the US” (submitted March 2021). Drug and alcohol use are often framed as antithetical to productive citizenship. For example, in public health analyses drug use is associated with unemployment. In this manuscript, interview data suggest that the relationship between drug use and work may not be stable. In some cases, drug use leads to losing work, but in other cases drug use makes work more possible. Social determinants of health have a temporality and spatiality.

These analyses use theories of ethics and relationality to contribute to the medical anthropology on care and the social determinants of health, also engaging with public health. These contributions speak to the possibilities for communities and states to respond to social distress through social services and interventions based on relationships, everyday practices, and institutional flexibility. My involvement with the Yavapai County Suicide Prevention Coalition and Yavapai County Overdose Fatality Review Board allow me the opportunity to disseminate research results to community stakeholders and contribute to ongoing dialogues around social distress and community responses.
